title: Right Triangles
description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse, master 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 special right triangle ratios, and introduce trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent) with real-world applications.
goals: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find missing side lengths in right triangles
Use the Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem to classify triangles
Apply properties of 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 special right triangles
Define and apply sine, cosine, and tangent ratios
Solve real-world problems using trig ratios and angles of elevation/depression
instructionalStrategy: Always label the hypotenuse first—it's always the longest side, always opposite the right angle, always c.
Use the visual proof with squares on each side to make a² + b² = c² concrete, not just a formula.
For special right triangles, teach the ratio patterns (1:1:√2 and 1:√3:2) rather than memorizing specific numbers.
SOH-CAH-TOA is a mnemonic, but understanding the ratios as relationships between sides and angles is the real goal.
Build from Pythagorean Theorem → converse → special triangles → trig ratios as a natural progression.

scaffold.title: The Pythagorean Theorem
scaffold.content:
The **Pythagorean Theorem** is one of the most important theorems in all of mathematics:

**a² + b² = c²**

where **c is always the hypotenuse** (the side opposite the right angle, and the longest side) and **a** and **b** are the two legs.

This works ONLY for right triangles. You can use it to find any missing side when you know the other two. If solving for a leg: a = √(c² - b²). If solving for the hypotenuse: c = √(a² + b²).

Common Pythagorean triples to recognize: **3-4-5**, **5-12-13**, **8-15-17**, **7-24-25**. Multiples also work (e.g., 6-8-10 is 2× the 3-4-5).
scaffold.initialPrompt: A right triangle has legs of 3 and 4. Before we calculate, take a guess—what do you think the hypotenuse is?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Pythagorean Theorem Applications

examples.problem: A right triangle has legs measuring 6 and 8. Find the hypotenuse.
examples.solution:
Identify: a = 6, b = 8, c = ?

a² + b² = c²
36 + 64 = c²
100 = c²
c = √100 = **10**

This is 2× the 3-4-5 triple (6-8-10).

examples.problem: A ladder is 13 feet long and leans against a wall. The base is 5 feet from the wall. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?
examples.solution:
Hypotenuse = ladder = 13, one leg = ground = 5, other leg = height = ?

5² + b² = 13²
25 + b² = 169
b² = 144
b = √144 = **12 feet** (5-12-13 triple!)

examples.problem: A triangle has sides 9, 12, and 16. Is it acute, right, or obtuse?
examples.solution:
Compare a² + b² to c² (c = longest side = 16):
9² + 12² vs 16²
81 + 144 vs 256
225 vs 256

225 < 256 → a² + b² < c² → **obtuse**

Rule: = right; > acute; < obtuse.

scaffold.title: Special Right Triangles: 45-45-90 and 30-60-90
scaffold.content:
**Special Right Triangles** have exact ratio patterns:

**45-45-90 Triangle** (isosceles right triangle):
• Legs are equal
• Hypotenuse = leg × √2
• Ratio: **1 : 1 : √2**

**30-60-90 Triangle** (half of an equilateral triangle):
• Short leg (opposite 30°) is the smallest
• Long leg = short leg × √3
• Hypotenuse = short leg × 2
• Ratio: **1 : √3 : 2**
scaffold.initialPrompt: In a 30-60-90, the hypotenuse is always twice the short leg. Why, if you think of it as half an equilateral triangle?

scaffold.title: Trigonometric Ratios: SOH-CAH-TOA
scaffold.content:
**Trigonometric Ratios** relate angles and sides of right triangles:

• **sin(θ)** = Opposite / Hypotenuse
• **cos(θ)** = Adjacent / Hypotenuse
• **tan(θ)** = Opposite / Adjacent

Remember: **SOH-CAH-TOA**

'Opposite' and 'adjacent' change depending on which angle you reference. The hypotenuse is always the same. To find a missing side, choose the ratio that connects what you know to what you need.
scaffold.initialPrompt: In a 3-4-5 right triangle, if the angle is opposite the side of 3, what is sin(θ)?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Trig Ratios and Applications

examples.problem: In a right triangle, the side opposite angle A is 5 and the hypotenuse is 13. Find all three trig ratios for angle A.
examples.solution:
sin(A) = opp/hyp = 5/13

Find adjacent: 5² + adj² = 13² → adj = 12

cos(A) = adj/hyp = 12/13
tan(A) = opp/adj = 5/12

Verify: sin²+cos² = 25/169 + 144/169 = 1 ✓

examples.problem: A right triangle has a 35° angle and hypotenuse of 20. Find the side opposite 35°.
From a point 50 feet from a building, the angle of elevation to the top is 40°. How tall is the building?
examples.solution:
tan(40°) = height / 50
height = 50 × tan(40°) = 50 × 0.8391 ≈ **42.0 feet**

We used tangent because we had the adjacent side (50 ft) and needed the opposite side (height).
